The Buddha said to the youth:
There are ten things for bodhisattvas to maintain pure precepts.
What are the ten?

First, fulfilling one's vows; second, learning the Buddha's path; third, always delighting in wisdom; fourth, not speaking falsely even unto death; fifth, not turning one's mind away from the world; sixth, abandoning birth and death; seventh, seeking nirvana; eighth, practicing in solitude; ninth, attaining samÄdhi; tenth, not engaging in poverty.
Young man!
These are the ten pure ways of upholding precepts for bodhisattvas.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Immediately fulfilling one's vows, learning the practices of the Buddhas;
Always delighting in the wisdom of the honored ones, without ever being afraid.
Not turning away from one's vows, nor turning away from the careful practices;
Always abandoning birth and death, then seeking the path to nirvana.
Always practicing in solitary places, then attaining samÄdhi;
Without ever being poor, upholding the precepts.
The person then fulfills all their wishes, and this bodhisattva studies the Buddhadharma;
The wise do not boast about others, and that person's precepts are thus pure.
Upholding the vow is very firm and not difficult, and one never again moves from what one has established;
Seeing the countless evils of birth and death, one then abandons them and seeks the path to nirvana.
The mind no longer becomes attached to thoughts, and that person thus establishes the precepts firmly;
Obtaining the correct land is unobstructed, and one with pure precepts has this practice.
The Buddha said to the youth:
There are ten things for a bodhisattva to establish patience.
What are the ten?

First, fire cannot burn them, second, blades cannot harm them, third, poison cannot take effect, fourth, water cannot drown them, fifth, non-humans protect them, sixth, they attain the marks that adorn their bodies, seventh, they block off all evil paths, eighth, attaining birth in the Brahma Heaven is not difficult, ninth, they attain peace and security day and night, and tenth, they attain bliss and do not waver.
Young man!
These are the ten matters of the bodhisattva's practice of patience.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Fire cannot burn that person, and blades also cannot harm them;
Poisons cannot take effect, and water also cannot drown them.
All non-humans protect them, and they immediately attain the thirty-two marks;
They then block off all evil paths. The virtues of the one who practices patience are like this.
Seeking the various Brahmas and Shakra, they are also not difficult to attain;
Always attain the practice of peace and comfort, and fully awaken to impermanent events.
Swords and fire cannot injure, and poison in the path cannot harm;
Celestial beings, humans, and spirits protect, and the one with patience has this practice.
In this very body, one attains the thirty-two marks, and that person no longer fears evil paths;
Upon death, one is immediately reborn in the Brahma Heaven. The one with a loving mind has this path.
Day and night, one attains the practice of peace and comfort, and always delights in the body attaining stability;
Towards all beings, one has a pure mind, and never has any intention of anger or resentment.
The Buddha said to the youth:
The diligence of bodhisattvas has ten aspects.
What are the ten?

First, they have majestic spiritual power; second, they are protected by the buddhas; third, non-humans also protect them; fourth, they never forget the Dharma they have heard; fifth, they attain hearing the Dharma they have not heard; sixth, they attain lofty and bright wisdom; seventh, they attain various samÄdhis; eighth, they are never ill; ninth, they attain peace and ease in food and drink; tenth, they attain softness like a lotus, not being rigid.
Young man!
These are the ten matters of the practice of vigor for the bodhisattva.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Always attaining majestic spiritual power, they never turn to commit evil;
All non-humans protect them, and they quickly attain Buddhahood.
They hear the Dharma and do not forget it, and seek to attain what they have not heard;
That person then attains loftiness and brightness. The one of vigorous practice has these virtues.
They attain the practice of various samÄdhis, and are never ill at any time;
Those who are diligent and wise together will attain the practice of the Buddha's path.
The food and drink they obtain brings peace and comfort, and they immediately attain diligent practice;
Just like a lotus in the water, gradually growing larger and fully blooming.
The pure and white Dharma is also like this, causing bodhisattvas to gradually accomplish;
There will never be anyone who can match them, attaining peace and bliss in the heavens.
The diligent practice of the TathÄgata, through diligence, surpasses countless eons;
The diligent practice of all bodhisattvas, all that they cultivate and uphold is explained.
Those who are diligent have majestic spiritual power, and are always protected by the buddhas;
They all respectfully receive and practice this path, and that person will soon attain the Buddha's path.
What they hear they will never forget, and they will also attain the practices of other dharmas;
The wisdom of that person will gradually increase - those who diligently practice have this.
Various samÄdhis always increase by themselves, and they will never have illness;
All food and drink they obtain will be peaceful and secure.
Day and night accomplishing pure practices, those who are diligent never rest;
Such a person will soon attain Buddhahood, and the honored one practices diligence in this way.
The Buddha said to the youth:
There are ten practices for a sitting-in-meditation bodhisattva.
What are the ten?

First, exclusively practicing abiding; second, practicing the path; third, having no fear or difficulty; fourth, being mindful of the various faculties; fifth, being loved by others; sixth, being far removed from desires; seventh, not turning away from single-minded concentration; eighth, being liberated from the realm of MÄra; ninth, abiding in the Buddha's realm; tenth, attaining liberation.
Youth!
These are the ten practices of a sitting-in-meditation bodhisattva.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
That person does not turn away from what they practice, and thus abides in the practice of the truth;
Devoted to practicing the affairs of the Way, that person abandons improper practice.
What is cultivated is no longer attached to, and the faculties have already become tranquil and still;
One thus attains peaceful joy, and sitting in meditation contemplates the affairs of the Way.
That person has already left behind desires, peacefully sitting in single-minded concentration;
Having distanced themselves from the realm of MÄra, they abide in the realm of the Buddha.
The devoted practitioner has this upholding, and he who delights in being alone under trees;
Will then have the practice of liberation, and accomplish the attainment of the ten phrases.
The bodhisattva who abides in turning away from non-practice, abandons all improper practice;
Abandoning improper practice and delighting in proper practice, one who contemplates samÄdhi has this matter.
That person will never have a time of attachment, the wise one who practices peacefulness does not crave;
With a good understanding of body and mind, one upholds the precepts. One who practices samÄdhi has these things.
Practicing in an empty tree grove, fearless, such a person will never be attached to greed.

Practicing patience and wisdom, he ultimately has no thought of a person;

The Buddha said to the youth:
The bodhisattva with much wisdom has ten practices.
What are the ten?

First, knowing the evil paths; second, knowing the good paths; third, understanding doubtful matters; fourth, manifesting the straight path; fifth, abandoning the evil paths; sixth, abiding in the right path; seventh, being at the gate of immortality; eighth, attaining to sit under the bodhi tree; ninth, manifesting the bright path for the people; tenth, not fearing the evil paths.
Youth!
These are the ten practices of the bodhisattva with much wisdom.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
In order to know all the afflictions, one thoroughly understands these two matters;
The person then abandons the afflictions and immediately follows the practice of the Buddha's path.
With wisdom, one understands all doubts and then manifests the matter of right views;
Then they abandon evil paths and practice, and immediately attain to be in the right path.
Seeing the gate to the sweet dew, they then attain to sit under the Buddha tree;
For the people, they manifest the right, and cause them not to fear the evil paths.
Understanding the innumerable dharmas of defilements, knowing the two matters are like this;
That person then abandons the defilements, and then studies the supreme good dharmas.
For all people, they resolve their doubts, and then attain to see the good and upright;
Then they abandon the matters of evil paths, and the greatly wise always abide in the path.
Always abiding in the gate to the sweet dew, they attain to sit under the innumerable Buddha trees;

The Buddha told the youth:
Bodhisattvas who revere the Dharma and uphold the Dharma to give to others have ten matters.
What are the ten?

First, abandoning evil; second, practicing goodness; third, cultivating the correct practitioner; fourth, purifying their buddha-land; fifth, sitting under the bodhi tree; sixth, giving away all possessions; seventh, subduing all afflictions; eighth, bestowing wisdom upon all people; ninth, practicing the mind of loving-kindness; tenth, attaining peace of mind in the present.
Young man!
These are the ten things by which a bodhisattva who upholds the sublime Dharma bestows the Dharma upon others.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Abandoning all that is unwholesome, practicing all wholesome things;
Attaining the wisdom of abiding in the Dharma, always delighting in giving.
Then purifying their buddha-land, attaining the unsurpassed land;
Then sitting under the bodhi tree, bestowing the Dharma like a treasure.
Giving away all possessions, then studying under the Dharma kings;
Then, far removing all dust and afflictions, it is not difficult for that person to attain Buddhahood.
Generously giving to all people, always having the practice of a compassionate mind;
Without any jealous or envious conduct, bringing peace and security to all non-human beings.
Much wisdom then abandons all unwholesome [actions], that person always abides in what is wholesome;
In the honored Dharma, firm and unmoving, the one with much wisdom always accords with the Dharma.
Then, always attaining a pure land, always revering and practicing the matters of the Buddha's path;
For always being able to be under the Bodhi tree, the one who gives the gift of Dharma has this matter.
Without any dust and afflictions, generously giving to the assembly, then immediately understanding one's own affairs;
All liberated from the matters of the world, that person will ultimately have nothing to obstruct or hinder.
That person himself knows and gives rise to the intention, generously giving like this for all people;
Those with a compassionate mind are free from jealousy, and see all dharmas as peaceful and without self.
The Buddha said to the youth:
The bodhisattva's practice of emptiness has ten aspects.
What are the ten?

First, practicing the Buddha way; second, practicing without attachment; third, not wishing for rebirth; fourth, not violating precepts; fifth, not slandering the wise; sixth, not engaging in disputes; seventh, having nothing to attain; eighth, practicing the path alone; ninth, not disputing the Buddha; tenth, accepting and practicing the Dharma.
Youth!
These are the bodhisattva's practice of ten empty aspects.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
The practices of the superior people lead to the attainment of the supreme world;
The courageous ones practice there, and cannot obtain life in any other place.
They are not attached to any world, and sit peacefully in meditation;
They also do not wish for any rebirth, and immediately understand all empty dharmas.
They will never again violate the precepts, and uphold the precepts without reproach;
They will not speak evil until the end of their lives, and will not slander other sages.
Their practice of the Way is without contention, and they will never have any disputes;
They will know all things, and practice in accordance with the Dharma.
Even to the point of losing their lives, they will never slander the World-Honored One;
They accumulate all dharmas, and guard their minds without fear.
In all worlds, the Buddha's Way is inconceivable;
They then uphold the Buddhadharma and no longer doubt the empty dharmas.
The practice of such a person is sublime, and they abide without being in any non-Buddhist paths;
Practicing meditation peacefully and without attachment, there are no lives and also no people.
Such a person will never have any attachment, and the one who practices single-mindedness has no thoughts;
Knowing that there are no people and no self-nature, there will also never be any wishes.
Fully understanding the matter of the empty nature of dharmas, one will never be attached to the myriad uses;
Such a person will never have thoughts of attachment, and will always have pure faith in the Buddha.
Such a person will never have disputes, and the solitary practitioner is empty of the myriad uses;
Such a person abides in the Buddha's path and upholds all the teachings of the TathÄgata.
The Buddha said to the youth:
There are ten things for a bodhisattva in solitary practice.
What are the ten?

First, having a pure mind; second, being free from desires; third, recollecting the buddhas; fourth, practicing with faith; fifth, having no doubts about wisdom; sixth, being grateful to the buddhas; seventh, not slandering the Dharma; eighth, practicing in solitude; ninth, attaining tranquility; tenth, having the wisdom to understand the four noble truths.
Young man!
These are the ten practices of a bodhisattva dwelling in solitude.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Never engaging in lustful activities, always having a pure mind;
Then, serving the affairs of desirelessness, practicing with a single-pointed mind in solitude.
Contemplating the illumination of the entire world, that person gradually develops faith;
Having no doubts about wisdom, the Buddha's wisdom is inconceivable.
Being grateful to the buddhas, the Buddha never abandons the Dharma;
Then, practicing in stillness, one abides in the Dharma of stillness.
That person will then attain understanding and enjoy being alone in the forest;
They will abandon wealth and pursue the path in one place.
That person will have a pure mind and always abandon evil things;
That person's practice of tranquility will be unsurpassed, and they will never again doubt the Buddha's wisdom.
That person will think of the unsurpassed Buddha and have faith in the practice of the Heaven of Heavens;
They will also never again doubt the Buddha's wisdom. One who practices tranquility will have this.
They will be grateful to the superior people and will never again abandon the practice of the Dharma;
One who practices alone in tranquility will have this.
They will attain the good and tranquil ground and will quickly understand all the realized things;
They will always explain countless sÅ«tras, and that person will have no obstacles.
The Buddha said to the youth:
Bodhisattvas have ten things when practicing in a secluded place.
What are the ten?

First, practicing in silence; second, staying far away from crowds; third, being free from disputes; fourth, being free from anger; fifth, not engaging in various practices; sixth, not engaging in blaming others; seventh, contemplating the matter of liberation; eighth, practicing with a peaceful and concentrated mind; ninth, quickly attaining liberation; tenth, attaining samÄdhi due to being free from attachment.
Young man!
These are the ten things for bodhisattvas to practice in a secluded place.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
Always having matters of silence, one then stays far away from crowds;
There will never be a time of disputes, yet one practices alone.
Always being free from an angry mind, one never becomes attached to the various realms;
Also not engaging in disputes again, staying in a secluded place has these virtues.

And one quickly attains transcendence.
Sitting alone in an upper secluded place, Always abandoning evil crowds and gatherings;
That person will never enter others' faults, One who sits among trees has this matter.
Then one becomes disgusted with all birth and death, That person has no greed for many uses;
Also, there are no matters of many fears, Sitting under a tree has this matter.
Never disputing with others, Always the solitary practitioner delights in tranquility;
Always guarding body, speech, and mind, The virtues of one in a secluded place are innumerable.

The Buddha said to the youth:
There are ten things in the bodhisattva's practice of alms-round.
What are the ten?
First, not wanting others to know about one's practice;
Second, not letting others know about one's merits;
Third, not having any desire for material gain;
Fourth, not boasting about oneself or being obsequious;
Fifth, abiding in the path of the sages;
Sixth, not speaking of one's own merits;
Seventh, not taking satisfaction from others;
Eighth, not being happy or sad when visiting others' homes;
Ninth, detaching from the giving of clothing and food, and giving the gift of the Dharma to others;
Tenth, abiding in virtue without obsequiousness, and taking up the gift of the Dharma.
Young man!
These are the ten things in the bodhisattva's practice of alms-round, abiding in virtue without obsequiousness.
The Buddha then spoke a verse, saying:
They do not want others to know their practice, nor are they attached to what they do;
Having the same attitude towards gain and loss, that person abides in the teachings.
They do not violate the affairs of the sages, and do not engage in flattery and deceit;
They do not boast of their own goodness, and do not speak ill of others.
They are neither sorrowful nor joyful, and expound the Dharma free from attachment to robes and food;
What they expound brings joy to all, this is the virtue of the alms-goer.
They do not seek fame or praise, and always abide in the four noble practices;
They have no flattery or deceit seeking material gain, those who receive the teachings have these things.
They do not boast of themselves or speak ill of others, and never speak ill of those with evil tongues;
Hearing of others' virtues, they are always joyful, the alms-goer knows contentment.
Free from attachment to robes and food, they give the Dharma well, and do not seek material gain;
What they expound brings joy to all good people, those who receive the teachings of the honored one have these things.
When the Buddha spoke this sutra, 72,000 people gave rise to the unsurpassed true path, and 10,000 bodhisattvas attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
The Buddha spoke like this. Manjushri Kumara, and all the assemblies of devas, nagas, and worldly humans were delighted. They came forward, bowed to the Buddha, and left.

The Sutra of the Samadhi of Moon-Lamp, in one fascicle. This is the Moon-Lamp Samadhi Sutra from the Tang canon, which is different in meaning from the sutras in the Song and Yuan canons. It is unknown which one is correct.
According to the Kaiyuan Catalog, this sutra has two separate translations:
One, in the section on translated but not extant, there is a translation by An Shigao of the Later Han dynasty in one fascicle;
Two, in the section on translated and extant, there is a translation by Monk Xian Gong of the Song dynasty in one fascicle.
They all say:
From the seventh fascicle of the Great Moon-Lamp Sutra.
Below the title of the translation by Xian Gong, a note says:
One is the Sutra of the Ten Practices of Manjushri Bodhisattva;
It also points out the length, saying:
One ten-page [sutra].
Now, examining this Dunhuang edition of the sutra, starting from the six perfections up to alms-begging, it covers twelve dharmas in total, all explained in terms of ten practices;
Moreover, its length is that of an ancient ten-page [sutra] with twelve lines, so it is known to be truly the Moonlight Sutra translated by Master Shi!
But the record says:
Extracted from the seventh fascicle of the Great Sutra, but now examining it, it is from the first half of the sixth fascicle, which is not quite right.
I suspect there are differences in the division of fascicles between ancient and modern times?
Or it is just a mistake in writing, changing six to seven?
